content: The "Universal National Service Act" includes provisions for national service obligation, induction, exemptions, conscientious objection, and discharge following service. It also amends the Military Selective Service Act to include registration of females and induction authority. The "Universal National Service Act" defines terms such as community-based agency, contingency operation, military service, and national service, which includes military or civilian service in government programs or with community-based organizations. The "Universal National Service Act" defines terms such as community-based agency, contingency operation, military service, and national service. The term "Secretary concerned" refers to specific government officials, and the term "United States" includes various geographical locations. The term "uniformed services" encompasses branches of the military. The term "uniformed services" includes branches of the military such as the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, Coast Guard, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and Public Health Service. SEC. 102. NATIONAL SERVICE OBLIGATION. Every citizen and resident in the United States aged 18-25 must perform national service, either military or civilian, to meet various societal needs as determined by the President. SEC. 103. INDUCTION TO PERFORM NATIONAL SERVICE. The President is required to induct individuals for national service, with limitations on induction for military service only during a declaration of war, national emergency, or when military forces are engaged in a congressional authorized operation. When military service induction is authorized, the President determines the number of individuals based on service end strengths and recruitment feasibility. Random selection mechanisms are used for both military and civilian service inductions. Persons who do not volunteer for military service or are not inducted will perform national service in a civilian capacity. Voluntary service allows individuals to choose national service instead of induction or request a different induction time. SEC. 104. TWO-YEAR PERIOD OF NATIONAL SERVICE. The period of national service under this title is typically two years, but can be extended by the President for medical care or training purposes. It can also be terminated early under certain circumstances, such as voluntary enlistment in the uniformed services. It can also be terminated early under certain circumstances, such as voluntary enlistment in the uniformed services. The admission and service of a person in an active or reserve component of the uniformed services for a period of at least two years will count towards the term of enlistment. Additionally, enrollment and service in an officer candidate program with an agreement to accept a Reserve commission may also qualify. Other grounds for service may be established by the President. SEC. 105. IMPLEMENTATION BY THE PRESIDENT. The President shall prescribe regulations for civilian service types, government programs, performance standards, and induction selection under this title. The President shall prescribe regulations for civilian service types, government programs, performance standards, and induction selection under this title. Selected individuals will be notified. Administrative matters, questions of inclusion/exemption, compensation standards, and other necessary matters will be determined for national service obligation. The President may use procedures from the Military Selective Service Act if appropriate. Procedures for registration, selection, and induction under the Military Selective Service Act (50 U.S.C. App. 451 et seq.) are provided. SEC. 106 requires physical and mental examination of individuals for national service classification. The President can set different standards for military and civilian service fitness. SEC. 107 covers deferments and postponements. High school students can postpone induction until they obtain a diploma, stop studying, or turn 20. Post-secondary students can delay induction until they get a certificate, stop studying, or reach 24. Deferments for extreme hardship or disability are also allowed. The President can delay military induction for basic training to limit the number of trainees. Deferments or postponements under this title end when the reason for them stops. SEC. 108. INDUCTION EXEMPTIONS. No person may be inducted for military service under this title unless acceptable for training and meets health/physical qualifications. Those serving honorably for at least six months in any uniformed service on active duty or cadets/midshipmen at specified academies are exempt from induction. Individuals can be exempt from military service induction if they are serving honorably for at least six months in any uniformed service on active duty or are cadets/midshipmen at specified academies, such as an accredited State maritime academy, a member of the Senior Reserve Officers' Training Corps, or the naval aviation college program, as long as they satisfactorily continue and complete at least two years of training. SEC. 109. CONSCIENTIOUS OBJECTION. Claims as Conscientious Objector: Individuals can be exempt from combatant training and service in the military if they have sincerely held moral, ethical, or religious beliefs against participating in war. They may be assigned to noncombatant service or ordered to perform civilian service if their claim is approved by the local board. Upon completion of national service, individuals are discharged from uniformed or civilian service without further obligation. This does not restrict the call to active service for members of the uniformed services. Additionally, females are now required to register under the Military Selective Service Act. SEC. 201 amends the Military Selective Service Act to require females to register for the draft. SEC. 202 addresses registration and induction authority. SEC. 202 amends the Military Selective Service Act by exempting induction into the Armed Forces under the Universal National Service Act.
